P001.name: James Wilson
P001.chief_complaint: Persistent cough with fever for 5 days, worsening shortness of breath

clinical_notes.author: Dr. Park
clinical_notes.content: 58M presents with 5-day history of productive cough with yellow-green sputum, fever (self-measured 38.5C at home), and progressive dyspnea. No hemoptysis. Reports decreased appetite and malaise. PMH significant for T2DM, HTN, hyperlipidemia. Chest auscultation reveals crackles in right lower lobe. Decreased breath sounds on right base. CXR pending.

P001.family_history: Father: MI at age 62. Mother: T2DM, alive. Brother: hypertension.
P001.social_history: Former smoker (20 pack-years, quit 5 years ago). Occasional alcohol use. Retired office worker. Lives with wife.

P002.name: Sarah Kim
P002.chief_complaint: Severe headache with neck stiffness and photophobia for 2 days

clinical_notes.author: Dr. Martinez
clinical_notes.content: 32F presents with severe headache (8/10) that started 2 days ago with progressive neck stiffness and photophobia. Reports fever at home. Denies recent travel or sick contacts. No history of immunosuppression. Kernig and Brudzinski signs positive on exam. This presentation is different from her usual migraines - more acute onset, higher fever, and nuchal rigidity.

P002.social_history: Non-smoker. Social drinker. Software engineer. No recent travel.

P003.name: Robert Chen
P003.chief_complaint: Acute right lower quadrant abdominal pain with nausea and vomiting

clinical_notes.author: Dr. Williams
clinical_notes.content: 45M presents with acute onset RLQ abdominal pain started 12 hours ago, initially periumbilical then migrated to RLQ. Associated nausea and 2 episodes of vomiting. Low-grade fever. McBurney's point tenderness positive. Rebound tenderness and guarding present. Psoas sign positive. Rovsing sign positive.

P003.family_history: Father: colon cancer at age 65. Mother: alive and well.

P004.name: Jessica Rivera
P004.chief_complaint: Sudden onset pleuritic chest pain with shortness of breath

clinical_notes.author: Dr. Thompson
clinical_notes.content: 38F presents with sudden onset right-sided pleuritic chest pain and dyspnea that started 4 hours ago while at work. Reports swelling in right calf for 2 days. Recently returned from a 12-hour flight from Seoul 5 days ago. On OCPs. BMI 34.2. Exam: tachycardic, tachypneic, mild hypoxia on RA. Right calf tender with 3cm circumference difference compared to left. CT-PA shows bilateral pulmonary emboli in segmental and subsegmental branches. RV/LV ratio 1.2 on CT. No saddle embolus.

P004.family_history: Mother: DVT at age 52. Father: healthy. No known coagulopathy history until current diagnosis.
P004.social_history: Non-smoker. Social drinker. Marketing manager. Frequent international business travel. Recent 12-hour flight Seoul to NYC 5 days ago.

P005.name: Marcus Johnson
P005.chief_complaint: Confusion, abdominal pain, and rapid breathing

conditions.notes: Diagnosed at age 14. History of poor compliance.

clinical_notes.author: Dr. Singh
clinical_notes.content: 24M T1DM brought by roommate for confusion and vomiting over last 12 hours. Reports running out of insulin 3 days ago due to cost issues. Roommate notes fruity breath odor. On exam: Kussmaul breathing, dry mucous membranes, poor skin turgor, diffuse abdominal tenderness without guarding. GCS 13 (E3V4M6). Classic DKA presentation with severe metabolic acidosis. Initiating DKA protocol: IV insulin drip, aggressive IVF resuscitation, K+ monitoring q2h.

P005.family_history: Mother: T2DM. Father: unknown. No family history of T1DM.
P005.social_history: College student. Non-smoker. Occasional marijuana use. No alcohol. Recently lost health insurance. Lives in dormitory.

P006.name: Dorothy Patterson
P006.chief_complaint: Vomiting blood and black tarry stools for 1 day

conditions.notes: Bilateral knees and hips, chronic NSAID use

clinical_notes.author: Dr. Garcia
clinical_notes.content: 72F presents with 3 episodes of hematemesis (coffee-ground to frank red blood) and multiple melanotic stools since yesterday evening. History of chronic NSAID use (naproxen) for OA plus daily aspirin for CAD. On PPI but started only 3 months ago. Hemodynamically significant — tachycardic and hypotensive on arrival. Orthostatic. Hgb 7.2 (baseline 12.5). BUN/Cr ratio >20 suggestive of upper GI source. Glasgow-Blatchford score 14 (high risk). Resuscitation with 2 units pRBC and IV crystalloid initiated. GI consulted for urgent EGD. NPO. Hold aspirin and naproxen. IV PPI (pantoprazole 80mg bolus then 8mg/hr drip).

P006.family_history: Father: died of MI at 68. Mother: osteoporosis. Sister: rheumatoid arthritis.
P006.social_history: Non-smoker. Glass of wine with dinner. Retired school teacher. Lives alone. Independent in ADLs.

P007.name: Frank O'Brien
P007.chief_complaint: Worsening shortness of breath and increased sputum production for 4 days

conditions.notes: FEV1 38% predicted. 3 exacerbations in past year.

clinical_notes.author: Dr. Murphy
clinical_notes.content: 66M with severe COPD (GOLD III, FEV1 38%) presents with 4-day history of worsening dyspnea, increased purulent sputum (green), and wheezing unresponsive to home nebulizers. Using accessory muscles, tripod positioning. Barrel chest. Diffuse expiratory wheezing with prolonged expiratory phase. ABG shows acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure (pH 7.28, pCO2 68 — baseline pCO2 ~52). O2 sat 82% on room air. Started BiPAP and IV methylprednisolone. Sputum culture sent. CXR shows hyperinflation without clear infiltrate. Considering ICU transfer if no improvement on BiPAP within 2 hours.

P007.family_history: Father: emphysema, died at 72. Mother: lung cancer. Brother: COPD.
P007.social_history: Active smoker, 45 pack-years. Drinks 2-3 beers daily. Retired construction worker. Lives with wife. On 2L home O2.

P008.name: George Nakamura
P008.chief_complaint: Severe epigastric pain radiating to back with nausea and vomiting

conditions.notes: Reports drinking 8-10 beers daily for past 6 years

clinical_notes.author: Dr. Yamada
clinical_notes.content: 48M presents with acute onset severe epigastric pain (10/10) radiating to back, started 8 hours ago after binge drinking episode. Multiple episodes of non-bloody vomiting. Reports 8-10 beers daily for 6 years with 2 prior episodes of 'pancreas problems.' On exam: distressed, guarding in epigastrium, decreased bowel sounds, no rebound. Cullen and Grey Turner signs absent. Lipase >17x ULN. CT abdomen: diffuse pancreatic enlargement with peripancreatic fat stranding, no necrosis on initial scan. Ranson's criteria at admission: 3 (age <55, WBC >16K, glucose 180, LDH pending, AST pending). BISAP score 2. Plan: aggressive IVF (250-500mL/hr LR), NPO, IV analgesia (hydromorphone PCA), CIWA monitoring for alcohol withdrawal risk.

P008.family_history: Father: alcoholism. Mother: gallstones. No family history of pancreatic cancer.
P008.social_history: Heavy alcohol use (8-10 beers daily x 6 years). Former smoker (10 pack-years, quit 2 years ago). Warehouse worker. Divorced. Lives alone.

drug_interactions.description: Fluoroquinolones may alter blood glucose levels when used with metformin. May cause hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia.
drug_interactions.recommendation: Monitor blood glucose closely. Adjust metformin dosage if necessary.

drug_interactions.description: ACE inhibitors increase potassium retention. Concurrent potassium supplementation may lead to hyperkalemia.
drug_interactions.recommendation: Avoid concurrent use or monitor potassium levels very closely.

drug_interactions.description: Macrolide antibiotics may increase the anticoagulant effect of warfarin, increasing bleeding risk.
drug_interactions.recommendation: Monitor INR closely. May need warfarin dose adjustment.

drug_interactions.description: Clarithromycin inhibits CYP3A4, significantly increasing statin levels and risk of rhabdomyolysis.
drug_interactions.recommendation: Avoid combination. Use azithromycin as alternative macrolide.

drug_interactions.description: Rifampin is a potent CYP3A4 inducer that significantly reduces oral contraceptive efficacy.
drug_interactions.recommendation: Use alternative contraception method during and 28 days after rifampin therapy.

drug_interactions.description: Risk of lactic acidosis. Metformin should be held before and 48h after iodinated contrast.
drug_interactions.recommendation: Hold metformin 48 hours before and after contrast administration. Check renal function.

GL001.title: ATS/IDSA Guidelines for Management of Community-Acquired Pneumonia
GL001.source: American Thoracic Society / Infectious Diseases Society of America
GL001.summary: Evidence-based recommendations for the diagnosis and treatment of community-acquired pneumonia in adults.
recommendations: For outpatient treatment without comorbidities: amoxicillin or doxycycline
For outpatient with comorbidities: respiratory fluoroquinolone OR beta-lactam + macrolide
For inpatient non-ICU: respiratory fluoroquinolone OR beta-lactam + macrolide
For inpatient ICU: beta-lactam + macrolide OR beta-lactam + respiratory fluoroquinolone
Obtain blood cultures and sputum culture before initiating antibiotics in hospitalized patients
Start antibiotics within 4 hours of admission
Consider local antibiogram for empiric therapy

GL002.title: IDSA Guidelines for Bacterial Meningitis Management
GL002.summary: Clinical practice guidelines for the management of bacterial meningitis.
recommendations: Perform lumbar puncture urgently if meningitis is suspected (unless contraindicated)
Start empiric antibiotics immediately - do not delay for imaging
Empiric therapy for adults: vancomycin + third-generation cephalosporin (ceftriaxone or cefotaxime)
Add dexamethasone 0.15 mg/kg IV q6h for 4 days, started before or with first antibiotic dose
Blood cultures before antibiotics
CT scan before LP only if: immunocompromised, history of CNS disease, new-onset seizure, papilledema, altered consciousness, focal neurologic deficit
Adjust antibiotics based on CSF culture and sensitivity results

GL003.title: SAGES Guidelines for Diagnosis and Treatment of Acute Appendicitis
GL003.source: Society of American Gastrointestinal and Endoscopic Surgeons
GL003.summary: Guidelines for the clinical diagnosis and surgical management of acute appendicitis.
recommendations: CT abdomen/pelvis is the imaging modality of choice (sensitivity >95%)
Ultrasound as first-line imaging in pediatric patients and pregnant women
Alvarado score ≥7 strongly suggests appendicitis
Laparoscopic appendectomy is the standard of care for uncomplicated appendicitis
Antibiotic-first approach may be considered for uncomplicated appendicitis in select patients
Preoperative antibiotics: single dose of broad-spectrum antibiotic
NPO status and IV fluid resuscitation before surgery
Pain management: avoid NSAIDs if GI bleeding risk; use acetaminophen or opioids

GL004.title: ESC/ERS Guidelines for Diagnosis and Management of Acute Pulmonary Embolism
GL004.source: European Society of Cardiology / European Respiratory Society
GL004.summary: Evidence-based guidelines for the diagnosis, risk stratification, and treatment of acute pulmonary embolism.
recommendations: Use Wells score or Geneva score for pre-test probability assessment
D-dimer testing to exclude PE in low-to-intermediate probability patients
CT pulmonary angiography (CTPA) is the gold standard imaging
Risk stratify using sPESI score, troponin, BNP, and RV/LV ratio on CT
Anticoagulation with LMWH or UFH for initial treatment
DOACs (apixaban or rivaroxaban) for most patients as first-line therapy
Systemic thrombolysis for massive PE with hemodynamic instability
Consider catheter-directed therapy for submassive PE with RV dysfunction
Thrombophilia workup in unprovoked PE in young patients

GL005.title: ADA Guidelines for Management of Diabetic Ketoacidosis
GL005.summary: Protocol for the acute management of diabetic ketoacidosis in adults.
recommendations: Diagnosis: glucose >250, pH <7.3, bicarbonate <18, positive ketones, elevated anion gap
Aggressive IV fluid resuscitation: NS 1-1.5 L/hr for first 1-2 hours
Continuous IV insulin infusion: 0.1 units/kg/hr (or 0.14 units/kg/hr without bolus)
Monitor potassium before starting insulin — replace if K+ <3.3 before insulin
Replace potassium in IV fluids when K+ <5.3 mEq/L
Monitor glucose hourly, BMP q2-4h
Switch to subcutaneous insulin when pH >7.3, bicarb >15, anion gap normalized, patient eating
Overlap IV and SC insulin by 1-2 hours
Identify and treat precipitating cause (infection, non-compliance, new-onset T1DM)

GL006.title: ACG Guidelines for Management of Upper Gastrointestinal Bleeding
GL006.summary: Clinical practice guidelines for diagnosis and management of upper GI bleeding.
recommendations: Risk stratify using Glasgow-Blatchford Score at presentation
Volume resuscitation — target MAP >65 mmHg
Transfuse pRBCs for hemoglobin <7 g/dL (or <9 g/dL in active coronary disease)
IV PPI: pantoprazole 80mg bolus then 8mg/hr drip (for high-risk patients)
EGD within 24 hours (within 12 hours for high-risk patients)
Hold aspirin/NSAIDs; resume aspirin within 3-7 days if cardiovascular indication exists
Erythromycin 250mg IV 20-120 minutes before EGD to improve visualization
For variceal bleeding: octreotide + antibiotics (ceftriaxone) + urgent EGD with banding
Interventional radiology or surgery for endoscopy-refractory bleeding

GL007.title: GOLD Guidelines for Management of COPD Exacerbations
GL007.source: Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease
GL007.summary: Management recommendations for acute exacerbations of COPD.
recommendations: Short-acting bronchodilators (SABA +/- SAMA) as first-line therapy
Systemic corticosteroids: prednisone 40mg/day for 5 days (or IV equivalent)
Antibiotics if increased dyspnea, sputum volume, AND sputum purulence (Anthonisen criteria)
Controlled oxygen therapy: target SpO2 88-92% to avoid CO2 retention
Non-invasive ventilation (BiPAP) for respiratory acidosis (pH <7.35, pCO2 >45)
Invasive ventilation if NIV fails, pH <7.25, or patient unable to protect airway
ABG monitoring for patients on supplemental O2 or NIV
VTE prophylaxis for hospitalized patients
Assess and optimize maintenance therapy at discharge

GL008.title: ACG Guidelines for Management of Acute Pancreatitis
GL008.summary: Evidence-based guidelines for diagnosis and management of acute pancreatitis.
recommendations: Diagnosis: 2 of 3 criteria — characteristic abdominal pain, lipase/amylase >3x ULN, imaging findings
Aggressive early IV fluid resuscitation: goal-directed (LR preferred, 250-500 mL/hr initially)
Monitor fluid responsiveness: urine output, heart rate, BUN trending
Pain management: multimodal analgesia, opioids as needed (no evidence against morphine)
NPO initially; start oral feeding when pain improving and no nausea
Early oral feeding (within 24 hours if tolerated) reduces length of stay
No role for prophylactic antibiotics in mild-moderate pancreatitis
CT abdomen with contrast at 72-96 hours if no clinical improvement (assess for necrosis)
ERCP within 24 hours for acute pancreatitis with cholangitis
Alcohol cessation counseling and follow-up for alcohol-related pancreatitis
